intro: Lagochilus kaschgaricus, commonly known as the Kashmir wallflower, is a flowering plant native to the high altitudes of the Himalayas. It belongs to the Boraginaceae family and is characterized by its compact growth habit and showy, brightly colored flowers. The plant typically produces blue or purple flowers with five petals, and its leaves are hairy and often glandular. It thrives in rocky, well-drained soils and is adapted to cold, arid environments. Due to its ornamental value and medicinal uses, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens and herbal practices.
